Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Game-theoretic Approaches to Energy Cooperation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy cooperation has the potential to transform wireless communication networks towards sustainable operation. By envisioning network devices that are not only energy harvesting from natural sources, but also from one another by means of energy transfer, overall network lifetime can be significantly extended with reliable operation and without relying on the power grid. Initial research studies in energy cooperation have assumed altruistic network nodes, willing to transfer their energy to others to sustain their operations. This project adopts a more realistic viewpoint where nodes would participate in energy cooperation to improve network performance when their actions simultaneously improve their individual performance.

This project aims to develop communication and networking mechanisms for next generation networks where nodes are engaged in energy cooperation. In particular, the project focuses on the strategic decision making framework that results in mechanisms to incentivize nodes to participate in such energy cooperating networks. The project consists of two trusts: incentivizing signal and energy cooperation and network formation via energy cooperation. The intellectual merit of the project includes combining techniques from optimization theory, game theory, communication theory, wireless networking and information theory to design energy-sustainable network operation and network formation schemes, physical layer cooperation and energy cooperation schemes. The broader impacts of the project include enabling green operation of wireless networks with longer network lifetimes, and educational broader impacts such as dissemination of research results in the form of tutorials, survey articles, lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has investigated wireless communication networks that are energy sustainable, by means of energy cooperation. The concept of energy cooperation allows the wireless nodes in a network to borrow energy from one another towards optimizing their collective throughput and network lifetime. Treating energy as a collective resource, such networks consist of nodes that can harvest energy from external sources as well as powering one another, and are the future of energy sustainability in communications.

 

The major technical outcomes of this project include the development of a strategic decision making framework that results in mechanisms to incentivize nodes to participate in such energy cooperating networks. In particular, a multi-leader follower framework for two-hop networks, where the source nodes wirelessly transfer energy to intermediate relays in order to facilitate end-to-end communication with destination nodes, has been established. Optimum transmission, wireless energy transfer and relay selection strategies have been identified using the Stackelberg framework with relay nodes as leaders. Furthermore, a communication protocol has been designed that enables the relay nodes to harvest energy from information signals that are unintended for them, and has been shown to improve the overall network utility. This protocol is termed asymmetric energy transfer. The major technical outcomes of this project also include identifying optimum resource allocation and network participation strategies for nodes for information freshness. For cognitive radio networks, networks that are wirelessly powered either from one another or by dedicated power beacons have been considered and age-of-information network formation and scheduling policies have been identified. Lastly, the project outcomes include utilizing machine learning techniques for offline and online resource allocation and transmission strategies for energy sustainable wireless communication networks.

 

Educational outcomes of this project has included incorporation of the produced research results into graduate curriculum, in particular in the form of a group of lectures as part of the graduate level course Emerging Topics in Networked Systems. Outreach activities have consisted of invited lectures and keynotes the PI offered at institutions, international conferences, and workshops.

 

Human development and training outcomes of this research include training of PhD students at Penn State and at Ohio State, on optimization, wireless communication theory, networking and wireless energy harvesting networks. The project enabled the participants to conduct research on energy-sustainable wireless communications, as well broadening participation in engineering through the training of two female doctoral students.
